div.p: 1. Walk in the Park this morning. Purchased Gibbon’s miscellaneous works. just published. And having dined at home, sat down to read the memoirs of his life written by himself. Between 11 & 12 at night I finished them; and my depravation must be very far advanced since I am disposed to consider this one evening thus employed as a glorious victory.

My ordinary day continues as at the last notice. Rise between 9 and 10. Sometimes later—proh! pudor! Breakfast & read the Times & Morning Chronicle. Dress, and by noon am prepared to write half a dozen lines.— Interrupted generally by some visitor: but have excluded almost every body. Have often a conference of two or three hours with Hall.— Walk or ride with the Ladies from 2. till dinner time. Evening at Mr: Johnson’s, and very often dine there. Home between midnight & 1. in the morning.— abed between 1. and 2.

2. Visit this morning to Mr: Boylston in Barnard’s Inn. Dined with Murdoch. He is very clever but his company is always strangely mixed. A frenchman by the name of Vanché there: a man of whom I had no opinion. Evening at Mr: Johnson’s. Hall Forbes, Russell & Foster there. Home late as usual.
3. Visit from Hall. Day remarkably warm. Dark. Thunder in the morning. Cleared up towards night. Dined at Mr: Johnson’s, and spent the Evening there. Murdoch came in quite late. To walk to-morrow.

4. Fine Weather. At Mr: Copley’ s. final sitting for my portrait. He has made a good picture of it Home just in time to keep my appointment with the Ladies. Walked in
St: James’s park.— Foster dined and passed pert of the Evening with me. Read Gibbon’s letters during the remainder.— Hall was engaged.— Second evening of victory, though weaker than the former.

5. Visits to Mr Dutille, to Mr: Rotch; and endeavoured to find Pitcairn & Rogers, but without success. Home and read a little. Evening at Mr: Johnson’s.— Backgammon, & a very pleasant time. Returned early, a good example to be repeated.

6. Visits, and luckily found nobody at home. Walk in Hyde-Park, the weather being very fine. At about 9 in the Evening, after reading well in Gibbon, went to Mrs. Hope’s Card Party. Was very early. Company amounted to several hundred persons. The collection of pictures very fine. I knew none of the ladies and very few of the men. The ministerial phizzes frown’d as usual, and received in return that reciprocation of contempt which was cordially felt. Introduced by Mr: Williams Hope, to Count Byland & Mr: Littledale. Some conversation with them. Sir John Sinclair told me he heard we were growing hostile again towards this Country. Answered him I hoped quite the contrary.— But this circumstance is far from pleasing to me, as I fear it is a symptom of bad intentions in the cabinet here.— I have to note that there was a large proportion of handsome women, and some very beautiful. Home between 11. and 12. Reading Gibbon again till my bed-time.

7. Hall called on me this forenoon. Went with him to see a menagerie or exhibition of birds and beasts in the strand. There are two Elephants, but the largest of them quite small. The others are hardly worth mentioning. Dined with W. Vaughan; the party not remarkably pleasant. Evening at Mr: Johnson’s.— Enivré peut être un peu, but not with wine. Read Gibbon on my return. Visit this morning from Dr: Romayne. He goes soon to Holland.
I cannot avoid the perpetual recurrence of my reflections on the manner in which my time is wasting away.— Yet I persuade myself at least that there is little fault of mine in it.

8. Attended a sale of Dr: Kippis’s books, but purchased nothing. Every thing goes off high at these sales, and we meet with no such opportunities as in Holland to make valuable purchases. Overtaken by the Ladies going to Mr: Johnson’s. Dined there & pass’d the Evening. Cards. Dull & insipid. Mr: Brooks.— Read more of the new publication of Gibbon.— finished the first volume.

9. Dined with Mr: Boylston. Barnard’s Inn. Mr: Logie, formerly the British Consul at Algiers was there; and a Mr: Moore, an American lately from France. Logie declares that he never had any instructions to instigate the Dey, against the United States. He says that the negotiation on our part has been strangely mismanaged from the great
number of People who meddled with it. I readily believe the fact. But the affairs of this Country there have not been better conducted; for they have paid £40,000 for settling a late difference there, which Logie says he would have settled for a fourth part of the sum.— Evening at Mr: Johnson’s.— Not well. prickd my finger, l know not how, but probably with a pin’s point.
10. Dined at Mr: Johnson’s, and pass’d the Evening there with Hall. Mr: Murdoch came in the Evening. Something resembling reproach from Mrs: Johnson. an explanation will be necessary.

11. Hall dined with me. The prick of my finger festers, and is not properly treated. Went to Drury-Lane theatre, and saw Macbeth with Harlequin Captive. Kemble was the Macbeth this Evening, and a better one than Palmer.

12. Official papers published. No Peace at present. Walk in the park. day and Evening at home. Reading Gibbon’s french journal & observations. His french is often defective. There is much sagacity in Lord Sheffield’s selection. He makes the most of his friends legacy, both in a personal and political point of view.

div.p: 13. Card this morning from Mrs: Johnson desiring to see me. partly apologetical, and partly spirited. Went accordingly. found Mr: Maitland at the door.— Came to a full explanation of my views and intentions, with Madam, upon the subject which was interesting to her: She declared herself satisfied. Went to find Hall, but met him with Cutting, and therefore returned alone to dine. Mr: Brooks came in after dinner. Went to Drury Lane Theatre with the Ladies. The Smugglers a new Farce, with songs. very indifferent; but well received. The Critic. intolerably long. The wedding day. in which Mrs: Jordan sung “In the dead of the night.” incomparably well. She is in her way almost or quite equal to the excellence of Mrs: Siddons. It was after twelve before the play was over, being the benefit night of young Bannister. I was set down at my lodgings. Hall & Mr: Brooks went home with the Ladies.
14. Called up early this morning by Dr: Romayne. Writing Letters. Dined at home alone. Evening at Mr Johnson’s. Cards with the Ladies. The time dull enough. Late home.

div.p: 15. Called early by Dr: Romayne. He is going to Holland. Walk before breakfast. My finger becomes troublesome; continued an improper treatment— Visits to Mr: Morris & to Mr Pinckney. Conversation to both such as I should have expected— Evening with Hall at Mr: Johnson’s. Something uncommonly out of course.— Played Whist, and lost.

div.p: 16. Dispersion of Spirits such that I can do nothing. Visit from Forbes, & from Mr. W. Vaughan. Dined at Mr: R. Bird’s. Company not numerous— Evening at Mr: Johnson’s. found company there— Required an explanation of last evening’s singularities, from Louisa— To have it soon. late home.

div.p: 17. Visit to Count Rumford. Not at home. Walk in the park and Kensington garden with Hall and Mr: Cutting. Weather fine, but dull. Dined at Sir F. Baring’s.— Time well enough. Evening at Mr: Johnson’s. To have my explanation from Louisa to-morrow. Mr: Murdoch there.

18. Dined and pass’d the evening at Mr: Johnson’s. Conversation with Louisa. Was explicit with her, and obtained her acquiescence.— The same with him. Upon one point however, the only one to which I must adhere, neither of them was satisfied.— The right and the reason of the thing are however indisputably with me, and I shall accordingly persist.

19. A day of trivial occupation. In the Evening to Mr: Johnson’s, and from thence with his family to a ball and supper given by Mr: & Mrs: Crickett and Mr: & Mrs: Townley at the free-mason’s tavern. Those gentlemen are Proctor’s in the Court of Admiralty, and give this entertainment by way of compliment to their neutral employers.— The day, as the anniversary of the battle of Lexington, gave rise to several reflections in my mind. The party was well enough but as all these parties have become in my estimation insipid The supper was good. Danced before and after it. Home between three and four. But it was almost five before I got to my lodgings, and broad day-light.— Was imprudent with my finger, and shall suffer the penalties of my indiscretion. Weather fine & warm.

20. Escaped a cold which I had apprehended, but found myself greatly fatigued, and heavy. My finger has suffered as I expected. Walked with Hall round the Park. idled away most of the day, and passed the Evening as usual.

21. The weather for several days has been remarkably beautiful. Wrote a little this morning. Dined with Mr: J. Taylor. Company American. Evening at Mr: Johnson’s, with Hall, Rogers, Forbes and Murdoch.— Backgammon and draughts.

22. Walk with Hall. as I was returning, met the young Ladies from Mr: Johnson’s. Rode with them round the park. Dined at home with Hall. Evening,—I might say at home too. It is more my home I think, than my own lodgings. Mrs: Johnson quite unwell.— Returned earlier than usual. An example worthy of imitation.

23. Was called for, and blundered as I always do. Dined en famille. Mr: Thorpe came in just after dinner, with his son from France. Singular effect upon Madam’s Spirits. communicated to Nancy.— Music.— Chess and Backgammon. Home early again.

24. Hall, and Russell, Murdoch, Cutting and Mr: Davis went this morning upon a tour to Oxford and Bath.— At home all the morning writing letters. Dined and spent the Evening at Mr: Johnson’s. Mrs: J. very low in Spirits, and unwell.— Weather very warm.

25. Writing again this forenoon. If I can recover my health, have some hopes of returning to a mode of existence rather more rational. Walk before dinner. Evening at my other home. Family partly unwell. Dispirited.— Backgammon.— Whist.

26 Finished a letter to my father. Wrote and read a little.— Evening as usual. Repining at a situation which seemed as if it never would end. The family recovered partly. But there are singular phenomena still discernible.— When I came home at night found a letter from the Secretary of State dated March 9. It is I think sufficient to authorize my return to the Hague, upon which I accordingly resolved immediately upon perusal of the letter.

div.p: 27. Called on Clarke this morning to enquire after an opportunity to go to Holland. He knows of none immediately, but will inform me as soon as possible. Went with Mrs: Johnson and the young ladies to see the Exhibition of paintings at Somerset house. Not long there. Went home with them to dinner. Several persons came in, in the afternoon and Evening. I am deemed unaccountable and meet with unaccountables. Some conversation however with Louisa, which unfolded part of what has appeared mysterious.— Invited to be of a party to-morrow, but was engaged.

28. Visit to see J. T. Sargent, but did not find him— Pass’d two or three hours at the exhibition Room. The English taste for painting at the present day is certainly vitiated; fashion is indeed always at variance with taste. At the present moment it admires Hoppner as a portrait painter. He appears to me to be quite inferior to Opie, who is himself fit for little more than a sign post. He has however one good thing at this exhibition called rural courtship. There are many portrait painters much superior to either of them, but whose talents are chilled by neglect because they are not fashionable. The fault of Opie is that his colours are harsh and stiff, with a vulgar appearance from which no one figure of his painting that I have ever seen is exempt. Hoppner’s defect is that he finishes nothing. All his pictures look half done, and have a studied indistinctness in every part of the picture except the face. Surely this is not the perfection of the art.
Clarke and Mr: Treat dined with me, and pass’d the Evening till 9. Remainder of the Eve at home.

29. Visit this morning to Mr: Pinckney. He was not at home. Saw Mr: Deas.— Home and wrote
wrote some letters. My finger which has been very troublesome begins to be relieved. Can therefore attend to something. Evening at Mr. Johnson’s. Some music

div.p: 30. Visit to Mr: Rigal, and Mr: Bird. Not to be found. Remainder of the morning read and wrote a little. Evening as yesterday. Conversation with Louisa. Mrs: J. and the other two young Ladies were gone out. They return’d to supper
